Vision general 
1. A pesar de que la disminucion de la mortalidad y el aumento de la 
esperanza de vida logrados en los dos ultimos decenios han side notables, 
Colombia continua haciendo frente a apremiantes problemas de salud, y en espe­
cial a una elevada mortalidad de ninos menores de un ano y de uno a cinco anos 
de edad. La importancia de las enfermedades cronicas aumenta rapidamente y 
con e1 tiempo demandaran una mayor proporcion de los recursos del sector. Hay 
grande:. disparidades regionales en cuanto a las condiciones y servicios de 
salud, y una cuarta parte de 1a pob1acion carece de atencion adecuada. Es 
eviden,:e que se ha progresado poco en e1 desarrollo del sistema naciona1 de 
sa1ud, debido principa1mente a 1a fa1ta de coordinacion entre e1 Ministerio de 
Sa1ud Publica (MSP) y e1 sector de seguridad social. E1 Ministerio sirve 
aproxb~adamente a 1a mitad de la pob1acion, haciendo hincapie en la atencion 
preven';iva y primaria de sa1ud, en tanto que el Instituto Colombiano de 
SeguroB Socia1es (ICSS) proporciona servicios principa1mente curativos a una 
decima parte de la pob1acion con un costo per capita cuatro veces mayor que e1 
del programa del Ministerio. La atencion primaria de sa1ud merece una alta 
prioridad y puede esperarse que contribuya a la reduccion de la mortalidad de 
ninos !1enores de un ana y de uno a cinco anos de edad. Un desafio de impor­
tancia cor.sistira en ap1icar simultaneamente medidas para p~evenir las enfer­
medadeH cronicas cuando sea posib1e y administrar en caso contrario tratamien­
tos quu pue~an cost ear los interesados. En 1978, Colombia gasto en salud 
US$46 per capita, equivalente a1 5,4% del PIB, nivel re1ativamente alto para 
un pai~; en desarrollo. En dicha cifra se inc1uyen los gastos de las familias 
por cOIlcepto de sa1ud. Los gastos por persona en 1978 fueron en promedio de 
US$28 Em e1 programa del Ministerio de Sa1ud y de US$108 en los de seguridad 
social. Las principa1es cuestiones a que se hace frente en e1 sector son las 
siguientes: 1) como asegurar la cobertura universal; 2) como disenar sistemas 
de obtEmcion de ingresos en que no se discrimine contra los pobres, y 3) como 
disminuir los costos, desa1entar e1 uso desmedido y fomentar sistemas de hono­
rarios que alivien 1a carga que pesa sobre los recursos generales del tesoro. 
Las opciones de politica comprenden una mayor coordinaci6n 0 grados variables 
de intEgraci6n de los sectores del Ministerio de Salud y de seguridad social, 
una rec'rientacion gradual hacia la presupuestacion por programas para los ser­
vicios de salud y el estab1ecimiento de una re1acion entre el n6mero de medi­
cos y las necesidades indicadas por las proyecciones. -ii ­
Situac:ion de Is pobl,scton,la saludy la nutricion 
2. La fecundidad y la mortalidad tanto general como infantil (es decir, 
de n1nos menores de un ano) han disminuido pronunciadamente en los dos ultimos 
decenios, se ha registrado una mejora del estado de la nutricion, han aumen­
tado los servicios de agua y alcantarillado, y la tasa de crecimiento anual de 
la poblacion ha bajado de mas del 3% al 2,1% anual. La disminucion de la 
fecundidad en mas de una tercera parte, fue una de las mas rapidas que se 
hayan registrado en cualquier lugar. Cerca de la mitad de las parejas casadas 
o que viven en union libre son usuarias corrientes de anticonceptivos. La 
mortalidad'derivada de la maternidad sigue siendo alta, principalmente debido 
a la inadecuada atencion obstetrica y a los abortos inducidos. La mortalidad 
general y la infantil han disminuido en cerca de la mitad desde comienzos del 
decenio de 1960 a consecuencia de mejoras en la nutricion, el agua y la salu­
bridad, y de la atencion de la salud. Si bien la mayoria de la poblacion esta 
mejor alimentada que hace dos decenios, una minoria apreciable, especialmente 
de ninos, permanece gravemente malnutrida. Dos tercios de la poblacion tienen 
acceso al agua por tuberia y mas de dos qUintos disponen de conexiones de 
alcantarillado, niveles que se cuentan entre los mas altos de America Latina. 
La tasa de crecimiento de la poblacion, a pesar de su disminucion reciente, 
continua limitando el desarrollo socioeconomico. 
3. Las condiciones de salud varian marcadamente: la mortalidad infan­
til en los departamentos mas pobres es mas de dos veces superior a la de zonas 
mas desarrolladas. Dichas condiciones son peores en la costa del Pacifico y 
en menor medida en la del Atlantico, en las regiones tropicales y entre los 
segmentos pobres de la poblacion rural y de la periferia urbana. Los proble­
mas de salud mas apremiantes son la alta mortalidad de ninos menores de un ano 
y de uno a cinco anos de edad a causa de la malnutricion y las enfermedades 
infecciosas, especialmente las diarreicas y las respiratorias; los accidentes 
y homicidios en el grupo de 15 a 44 anos de edad, y las enfermedades cronicas 
(especialmente la hipertension, las enfermedades del corazon, el cancer, y los 
derrames cerebrales) en los de 45 anos y mas. Las seis causas de muerte prin­
cipales para todas las edades combinadas son, en orden de importancia, el can­
cer, la isquemia cardiaca, otras cardiopatias, las enfermedades diarreicas, 
los derrames cerebrales, y la neumonia. Puesto que la mortalidad de los ninos 
menores de cinco anos representa en 1a actualidad un tercio de todas las muer­
tes (que se compara con la mitad de ese total como promedio en los paises de 
bajos ingresos) y se registra una'prevalencia creciente de enfermedades. croni­
cas, accidentes y homicidios, Colombia hace frente a un doble desafio en el 
sector salud. En primer lugar, como emplear mas eficazmente los recursos de 
que dispone para la atencion primaria de salud CAPS) dirigida a reducir el 
nUmero de victimas de enfermedades infecciosas agudas, especialmente diarrei­
cas. En segundo lugar y simultaneamente, Colombia debe centrar su estrategia 
sectorial en la prevencion de las enfermedades cronicas cuando ello sea posi­
ble, y en su tratamiento y control cuando no 10 sea. De manera especial, es 
menester que se emprendan campanas preventivas (por ejemplo, en relacion con 
el uso del tabaco y la hipertension) y se organicen los recursos sectoriales a 
fin de evitar la costqsa preponderancia del cuidado cur~tivo con empleo de 
alta tecnologia que es caracteristi~o de los paises mas desarrollados. -iii -
Politicas y actuaci6n del sector 
4. En 1975, el Gobierno cre6 el Sistema Nacional de Salud para coordi­
nar y finalmente integrar las instituciones del sector. En el Plan Nacional 
de lntegraci6n de 1979-82 se hizo hincapie en la ampliaci6n de la cobertura a 
grupos (madres, ninos pequenos) y zonas (rurales y de la periferia urbana) 
vulnerables. En dicho plan se fijaron metas para la reducci6n de la morbili­
dad y :la mortalidad y para la cobertura con servicios como e1 de inmunizacio­
nes. Empero, no se ha podido precisar la medida en que se hayan alcanzado 
estas netas. 
5. Los principales proveedores en el sector son el Ministerio de Salud 
Publica (MSP) y los Servicios Seccionales (departamentales) de Salud (SSS) 
(que atienden al 45% de la poblaci6n), el Instituto Colombiano de Seguros 
Socialns (ICSS) (10%), aproximadamente otras 200 entidades publicas y privadas 
de se~lridad social (5%) y el sector privado (15%). Una cuarta parte de la 
poblac:.6n carece de acceso efectivo a servicios de atenci6n de la salud. En 
conjunto la infraestructura fisica, con excepci6n de los departamentos mas 
pobres y preponderantemente rurales, es suficiente para alcanzar una cobertura 
univer~;al. 
6. Colombia tiene un nUmero suficiente de medicos y personal de enfer­
meria nn las zonas urbanas, pero muy escaso en las regiones rurales. Es pro­
bable que la producci6n de medicos exceda la capacidad de absorci6n en· un 
periodo de tres a cinco anos. Colombia necesita examinar urgentemente esa 
producc:i6n con el objeto de determinar si se justifican, a la luz del exceso 
previs: ..ble, las subvenciones que se conceden actualmente a las escuelas de 
medicina. 
7. El sector privado atiende mas consultas medicas que el MSP y los SSS 
combinados (MSP/SSS) 0 que las entidades de seguridad social. El sistema 
MSP/SS~; atiende un tercio mas de consultas que el lCSS. A los beneficiarios 
del lCSS corresponden en promedio mas de tres visitas de pacientes externos 
poranc), frente a menos de una visita anual, que es el promedio de los pacien­
tes del MSP/SSS. Dos tercios de las hospitalizaciones ocurren en estableci­
mientm; del MSP/SSS, aproximadamente una de cada cinco en instituciones priva­
das y una de cada siete en hospitales del lCSS. La disminuci6n registrada en 
el promedio del tiempo de hospitalizaci6n y el aumento del numero de pacientes 
dados de alta por ano-cama indican una creciente eficiencia en el uso de los 
hospitci.les. Sin embargo, las tasas de ocupaci6n varian ampliamente, de un 
extremel alto en el nivel terciario (hospitales universitarios) a otro inefi­
cientemente bajo en los niveles secundario (regionales) y primario (locales). 
Las tasas de utilizaci6n de hospitales son elevadas en 10 que respecta a los 
benefic.iarios mas acomodados y del ICSS, y bajas en cuanto a los pobres. 
8. Las.tasas de inmunizaci6n son relativamente bajas en Colombia y van 
de apre,ximadamente un tercio a la mitad los ninos menores de cinco anos a los 
que se ha administrado vacunas BCG y OPT y han side inmunizados contra la 
.poliomjelitis 	 y el sarampi6n. .Poco mas de la mitad de los n~cimientos ocurren 
en instituciones de salud, cerca de la mitad son atendidos por medicos y una 
cuarta parte por parteras empiricas. -iv • 
9. Algunos problemas se manifiestan claramente en el sistema de servi­
cios de salud. El programa de atencion primaria de sa1ud del MSP/SSS no tiene 
personal ni fondos suficientes y no puede alcanzar sus ambiciosas metas de 
ampliacion de su cobertura. La capacitacion, la supervision y el apoyo logis­
tico inadecuados son problemas adicionales y no se ha demostrado la eficacia 
del modelo de atencion primaria de salud. Ademas, la falta de personal, equi­
pos y suministros en los hospitales regionales hace que los pacientes pasen 
por alto este nivel secundario y vayan directamente al nivel terciario de 
atencion de la salud. Esto significa que los servicios del nivel terciario 
proporcionan atencion primaria de salud a un elevado costo. 
10. Hasta epocas recientes, el rcss proporcionaba principalmente servi­
cios curativos de alto costo y tenia una excesiva tasa de hospitalizacion. A 
consecuencia de una crisis ocurrida en 1977 se introdujeron cambios flnsncie­
ros y admlnistrativos y se emprendio un programa de APS para aumentar la efi­
ciencia. El ICSS contrata camas de hospital y servicios de consulta externa 
con el MSPjSSS, pero hay una limitada coordinacion entre las instituciones. 
La Superintendencia de Salud, creada en 1979 para alentar la coordinacion, no 
ha resultado eficaz. Tanto el MSPjSSS como el rcss planifican sus servicios 
independientemente y a menudo se superponen al atender unas mismas zonas geo­
graficas, dando como resultado una subutilizacion.de recursos. 
11. Al Ministerio de Salud Publica corresponde nominalmente la responsa­
bilidad de todo el Sistema Nacional de Salud. Su autoridad financiera com­
prende solamente los institutos afiliados y los servicios de salud departamen­
tales, que representan menos de un tercio de los gastos totales del sector. 
Al sector de seguridad social corresponde mas de un tercio .de los gastos de 
atencion de la salud. El sector privado representa el tercio restante. Los 
gastos medios p~r persona en 1978 fueron de US$108 en los programas de seguri­
dad social y US$28 en los del MSPjSSS. La participacion del MSPjSSS en el PIB 
disminuyo durante el ultimo decenio, pero su cobertura aumento en tanto que el 
promedio de visitas por persona permaneeio constante durante dicho periodo, 10 
eua1 indica un aumento de la eficieneia. 
12. El problema dominante que enfrenta el MSPjSSS es el insuficiente 
financiamiento de los costos ordinarios de atencion de salud. La atencion 
hospital aria representa el 69% del presupuesto del MSPjSSS, pero sin embargo 
persisten los deficit cronicos. El reciente plan de inversiones en instala­
ciones de salud no ha estado acompanado de la necesaria asignacion de mas . 
fondos para costos de funcionamiento. 
Financiamiento de la atencion de la salud 
13. La asignacion de fondos nacionales suministra al presupuesto del 
sistema MSPjSSS aproximadamente dos tercios de sus recursos y las fuentes 
departamentales alrededor de un tercio. Las fuentes nacionales son el presu­
puesto ordinario del Gobierno Central, el "situado fiscal" --proporcion del 
presupuesto nacional destinada a educacion y salud-- y prestam~s. internos y 
externos. Las fuentes departamentales.comprenden los ingresos derivados de - v ­
loterias, impuestos a la cervezay los licores J y las ventas de servicios. La 
fr"ecuente necesidad de recurrir a asignaciones extraordinarias en el presu­
puesto nacional y la incertidumbre con respecto al monto y oportunidad de los 
ingresos departamentales tienen por consecuencia graves problemas de flujo de 
fondos .. 
14. Los servicios de salud del ICSS se financian mediante una contribu­
cion igual al 7%'de los sueldos y salarios (0 el 12% en el caso de la cober­
tura de una familia completa), de la cual corresponden dos tercios al emplea­
dor y 1m tercio al empleado. La cobertura ordinaria es completa solamente 
para e1 empleado pero comprende servicios de maternidad y cuidado de niiios 
menoreH de un aiio. Un gasto de US$l1.3 por beneficiario (frente a $108 para 
todas :Las entidades de seguros sociales combinadas) en esta poblacion relati­
vamentl! saludable significa altos costos e ineficiencia. 
Probleuas y opciones 
15. Los problemas preponderantes del sector salud se refieren a la equi­
dad, lil eficiencia y la eficacia: 
Equidad -como corregir las desigualdades regionales en cuanto 
a las condiciones y servicios de salud para alcanzar 
una cobertura universal en 1990 y reducciones apre­
ciables de la mortalidad y la morbilidad en los 
departamentos pobres para ese mismo ano; 
Eficiencia -como emplear los recursos humanos, institucionales 
y de administracion disponibles para alcanzar las 
metas generales del sector; 
Eficacia -como alcanzar las metas del sector dentro del marco 
de los factores que limitan los nuevos aumentos de 
la proporcion del PIB 0 de los ingresos del Gobierno 
Central que representan los recursos dedicados a 
gastos de atencion de la salud. 
Estos problemas entraiian a su vez la necesidad de adoptar decisiones de poli­
tica pnra perfeccionar y ampliar los modelos de atencion primaria de salud, 
organi~:ar la administracion y e1 financiamiento de los servicios en este campo 
a fin de proporcionar incentivos para e1 uso eficaz de los recursos, y recon­
sideral: 1a asignacion actualmente excesiva tanto de ingresos como de gastos 
que va en desmedro de la administracion del sector, del control financiero y 
de la husqueda de modalidades eficientes de prestacion de servicios. 
16. . Las principales opciones de politica que tienen ante si las autori­
dades eolombianas se refieren a la oportunidad y modo de poner en ejecucion el 
Sistema Nacional de Salud. Las mas importantes opciones consisten en integrar 
el MSP/SSS y los organismos de seguridad social 0 coordinar los dos sistemas. 
Si bien la integracion representa e1 rumbo mas difici1 de .seguir, por 10 menos -vi ­
a. ..corto ..pl.azo, ..par.e.ce.,ser,el .Unico .,que . .a.segu.re ·un .sis:tema. desal:udnac.ional 
con cobertura universal y normas de servicio uniformes. Sin embargo, las 
dificultades que en la practica se oponen a la integracion son tremendas. Los

1. Health, water supply and sanitation components were included in 
Loan 1487-CO under the National Food Program (PAN) and in Loan 1352-CO 
under the Integrated Rural Development Project (DRI I). Both loans are 
scheduled to close in December 1983. In addition, a Second Integrated 
Rural Development Project (DRI II), including further health components, 
was recently appraised (SAR dated May 7, 1982). A description of these 
components and their performance to date follows. 
PAN 
2. The overall objective of this project is to improve the nutrition 
conditions, living standards and production potential of around 1.8 million 
persons living below the poverty line. The project uses the national 
health system for nutrition surveillance and delivery of integrated nutri­
tion/health services, including nutrition education, food supplements, 
environmental sanitation, promotion of family gardens and family planning 
services. The primary health measures rely principally on parapro­
fessionals recruited from within the communities they serve and emphasize 
preventive rather than curative care delivered through community health 
posts. 
3. Project funds are being used to construct 56 and renovate 225 
community health posts in rural and urban areas for training around 2,028 
health promoters and 677 auxiliary nurses, and for 2,400 medical kits. In 
addition, the project provides medical supplies, vaccines, mules and 
bicycles for health workers and communications equipment for rural health 
posts. The project would also finance consultant services to the Ministry 
of Health and the seven regional health services (SSS) in the project 
regions. 
4. Assistance is being provided to double the project area popula­
tion with access to potable water through around 360 rural water supply 
systems serving 231,000 persons in 372 sm~ll communities also served by 
health posts. This component also provides fixtures, building materials 
and venicles for the Ministry of Health to install 112,000 household 
latrines serving 627,000 persons. Provision of water supply systems and 
latrines is being synchronized, where possible, with installation of health 
posts. 
5. Of the estimated US$55.1 million in project base costs, USS15.1 
million is for health services and US$18.4 million for water supply and 
sanitation. -96 - Annex 1

PNS Evaluation 
1. The health sector's overall development strategy is being carried 
out under the National Health Plan (PNS) started in the mid-1970's. PNS 
evaluation was completed in March, 1980. It consisted of (a) an analysis 
of data generated by MS information systems; (b) a cross-sectional survey 
of 22 SSS, and a representative sample of 150 basic health (MAC) units and 
their beneficiaries. In spite of methodological flaws which limit inter­
pretation of findings, results of the evaluation summarized below have been 
useful in underscoring the need to revise norms and tmprove supervision of 
the PNS. 
2. The Appendix summarizes the number of MAC units programmed in 
relation to those actually installed for the years 1976 -1978. In order 
to quallfy as installed, a MAC had to be functioning with at least 3 proino­
toras and 1 auxiliary nurse. More recent information indicates that over 
700 MACs were successfully installed during the first three-and-a-ha1f 
years of the PNS. Performance by departamentos varied. Some reached 100 
percent while others, like Cordoba and Narino, accomplished only 20 percent 
of goal. The Appendix summarizes the planned and achieved coverage of the 
program. The goal was to increase the number of persons covered at the 
rate of one million per year. Apparently, it is being achieved. However, 
the definition of coverage is not clear. According to MS sources, the 
figures in the Appendix are a composite of two types of estimates: (a) in 
rural areas the actual number of beneficiaries contacted by the promoters 
was rep,')rted while (2) in urban sites, the entire population of the area 
where t't1e MAC was installed was used to calculate coverage. The latter 
method yielded an inflated figure, clearly an overestimate. Since one­
third oE the sample of MACs utilized in the sample were located in Bogota, 
the cov'!rage figure is not accurate. The fact that only 1,500 promotoras 
were on the payroll at the end of the first semester of 1979 suggests that 
the cov,!rage was considerably less than that reported. Each promotora in 
rural a",:,eas was able to cover 500 persons at most, of the 1,000 originally 
planned. It 1s estimated that urban promotoras can reach considerably 
higher :lumbers, but probably not more than 2,000 persons. If it is assumed" 
that 50 percent of MACs are urban, coverage would amount to a maximum of 
1.9 million, rather than 3 million. 
3. As detailed in previous reports, the evaluation disclosed 
significant shortfalls in construction of health centers and health posts. 
During the first three years, only 38 percent of new construction was 
completed and 67 percent of planned repairs and remodelling were 
acc.omplished. Only q percent of auxiliary nurses and 67 percent of 
promoto~as were properly equipped. · -100 - Annex 2

4. Since each promotora is presumably equivalent to 2,000 hours per 
year, 4.3 million hours budgeted for 1979 implies that there were positions 
for approximately 2,150 promotoras or 60 percent of the number required to 
fully staff the 650 MACs then in operation. Since only 75 percent of the 
budgeted positions were filled, the number of promotoras actually in 
service was closer to 1,500. This implies significant understaffing of the 
system, i.e. (2.8 vs. 6 promotoras per MAC), or less than half the number 
needed to fully staff the 650 MACs. Field visits during supervision mis­
sions suggests one explanation: health services are short of operating 
funds and therefore tend not to replace promotoras who resign. Thirty-six 
percent of the total number of visits planned were carried out by the 
promotoras. They were programmed to cover 45 percent of the 1,202,000 
families theoretically served by the system. Only 20 percent of that goal 
was achieved, suggesting that the number of families reached by the promo­
toras was in the neighborhood of 250,000. Assuming five members per 
family, the total population covered was approximately 1.2 million 
persons. Utilizing standard recurring operating costs per MAC, i.e., 
approximately 1.1 million 1981 pesos per annum, it would follow that the 
cost of delivering services to 1.2 million persons was 650 x 1.13 million + 
650 pesos per capita per year or 13 dollars. Considering that these are 
primarily preventive and educational services, and that they do not include 
curative medicine beyond the physician visit at the health post, the figure 
is high; however, it could be justified if the system resulted, as origi­
nally conceived, in progressive reduction of morbidity, mortality and 
consultations to more expensive echelons of the system. 
5. More qualitative opinion-type surveys conducted as part of the 
1979 evaluation, together with supervision visits to a small number of MACs 
and discussion with MS personnel suggest that the success of the PNS 
continues to be threatened. Political commitment, although recently reaf­
firmed by government, is faltering because of increasing economic pressures 
that have accentuated competition between urban, curative establishments -­
more politically fruitful --and rural sanitation, education and preventive 
efforts --whose target is primarily the politically disenfranchised. 
Inflation and the decision to pay promotoras minimum salary have resulted 
in an unexpected escalation of operating costs. Government is under pres­
sure to resolve administrative and policy programs imposed by the need to 
integrate the PNS, urban health care, and the social security health 
system. Persistent difficulties in staffing and organization of the MS 
Programming Office, the unit responsible until recently for carrying out 
the PNS, has weakened leadership and quality control. Moreover, deficient 
local management in many departamentos has impeded development of effective 
vertical supervision necessary to evaluate initial experience and adjust 
methods of implementation and policy design. The data collected in 1979 
did not allow quantification of either cost (which was expected), or bene­
fits (reduction in the risks of dying or becoming ill); at this early stage 
such data could only be valid if collected through meticulous supervision 
and quality control. Effectiveness of promotoras as health sanitati~n 
educators and primary care providers remains untested. At present, the 
cost of the innovative, community-based c~ponent remains speculative.

by piecing together increments in government resource allocations, private 
sector contributions (Coffee Growers Association), and international loans; 
and (f) decentralize planning, budgeting and funding of health activities 
to the SSS to promote regional development, appropriate policy and local 
financial responsibility. 
12. With these tasks in mind, MS sought the counsel of competent 
Colombi.ln health planners and public health experts. PINDESA has been the 
result f;f these consultations and analyses. PINDESA's main objective is 
"to overcome obstacles to the full implementation of the PNS necessary to 
meet the challenge that the Government of Colombia has formally accepted: 
provisiclU of health care for everyone by the year 2000." The objectives 
are to effectively organize and involve the beneficiaries in the organiza­
tion of primary care and to mobilize the necessary sectorial and intersec­
torial l-esources to support them in that effort. The specific goals are 
to: (a') support and coordinate the process of regional health policy plan­
ning and the delivery of services by pooling resources and involving the 
local universities. Particular attention will be paid to supervision and 
increments in effectiveness and efficiency; (b) promote the organization 
and par1:icipation of each community in the diagnosis and solutions of their 
own hea:.th problems; (c) develop appropriate technology; (d) develop the 
require(:: professional human resources through task-oriented training; and 
(e) tratn auxiliary personnel and devise effective methods to integrate 
them into the system, supervise them and stimulate them. 
13. PINDESA follows WHO guidelines. It entails the organization of a 
central nucleus located at MS in Bogota and at least· six regional or peri­
pheral tmclei located in the cities of Bogota, Bucaramanga, Cali, 
Cartaget~, Manizales, and Medellin. The central nucleus and the peripheral 
units in Cali and Medellin are already in place. 
14. The functions of the Central Nucleus are to orient, coordinate 
and intE!grate resources in order to implement the Plan policy. Specifi­
cally it will: (a) define Plan policies; (b) program Plan activities in 
coordin~tion with peripheral nuclei; (c) promote partiCipation of health 
sector Etgencies and that of other sectors relevant to PINDESA objectives; 
(d) foralalize agreements, contracts, work plans, and budgets, the partici­
pation (If both private institutions and the peripheral nuclei; (e) super­
vise and periodically evaluate programs and projects; and (f) create new 
peripheral nuclei as necessary. 
15. The Central Nucleus consists of an administrative board and an 
executive committee. The board members are the Vice Minister of Health who 
presides it; MS's Chief of Planning, and the Director of Research; the 
Head of DNP's Health Division; the Executive Director of ASCOFAME; a repre­
sentative of WHO-PAHO, and a delegate from each of the peripheral nuclei. 
The board assigns financial resources and coordinates the development .of -104 ­Annex 2 
Page 6 
periph~ral nuclei programs. In addition, the board evaluates new programs 
proposals and supervises the results of projects conducted 'by peripheral 
nuclei. Lastly, the board is responsible for communicating program results 
and ensuring that newly developed methods are applied by the Servicios 
Seccionales de Salud. 
16. The executive committee of the Central Nucleus is composed of 
MS's Secretary General who will preside it and the Directors of Research 
(who will be its secretary), Planning, International Affairs, Health Care, 
Environmental Sanitation and Human Resources, as well as appropriate 
consultants. The executive committee is to carry out the board's decisions 
and other tasks assigned by the board. 
17. The peripheral nuclei support the planning, implementation and 
evaluation of regional health services in their departamentos within their 
area of influence. Specifically, these nuclei collaborate with the depart­
mental SSS in the design of systems, strategies, methodoiogy --both tech­
nical and administrative, and in applied research to detect problems and 
improve the health services in the region. The nuclei will also coordinate 
development of profeSSional and paraprofessional human resources for the 
health sector through applied education research and development of educa­
tional materials including case studies. Research results will be communi­
cated within the region and to other areas where they may be applicable. 
The nuclei will advise the SSS and other local health institutions and 
exchange information of the results obtained regarding implementation of 
innovative systems and appropriate methodology. 
18. Each peripheral nucleus will have a board and an executive 
committee. The board consists of the Chief of the Servicl0 Seccional de 
Salud and the Chief of Planning of each of the area departamentos, a repre­
sentative of each of one of the local universities with a health science 
component, representatives of other relevant entities --ISS, ICBF, munici­
pal health units, cafeteros, etc. --and one representative of the central 
nucleus. The board will be presided by the Head of the SSS of the departa­
mento where the nucleus is located. 
19. The functions of the executive committee in the peripheral nuclei 
are: to propose programs and plans, and to supervise and evaluate the 
results of the programs and projects. The executive committee of each of 
the peripheral nuclei will include the Coordinador Tecnico of each one of 
the Servicios Seccionales de Salud in the area of influence, a represent­
ative of each of the local universities with a health science component, 
and appointed representatives of other relevant entities as in the case of 
the board. The executive committee will be presided by the Coordinador 
Tecnico of the Servicio Secciona1 de Sa1ud of the department where the 
nucleus is locat~ with the support of a full-time health professional in 
charge of coordinating and supervising the development of the nucleus 
programs. -105 - Annex 2 
Page 7 
20. The functions of the executive committees are: ta implement the 
decisions of the board and to execute the programs and projects of the 
nucleus. 
21. The boards of directors will meet at least twice a year. The 
executive committees will meet monthly. The above described structure will 
be monitored by a committee composed of a WHO consultant and two MaR 
officers appointed by the Minister. 
22. MS approved PINDESA in June 1981; shortly thereafter, the central 
nucleus was organized. In July 1981, the peripheral nucleus of Valle, 
Cauca, Narino and the Intendencia de Putumayo was inaugurated in Cali. The 
regional nucleus with headquarters in Manizales was organized in August. 
It comprises the department of Caldas, Risaralda and Quindio. The organi­
zation of nuclei in Bogota and Medellin-Antioquia is planned for the near 
future followed by others in Villavicencio, Bucaramanga and Cartegena. 
23. PINDESA is in effect a mechanism to significantly increase commu­
nication and collaboration between the SSS, ICBF, ISS Cajas, and universi­
ties. They have been directed to pool their resources to detect barriers 
to the implementation of the PNS and, through operational research, devise 
means to overcome them. 
24. Whether PINDESA will be successful remains to be seen. At best, 
it could catalyze the application of extraordinary talent of Colombia 
health scientists to the solution of high priority national problems. At 
'worst, it may foster the further enlargement of an already oversized 
bureaucracy. Much will depend on the leadership provided by the central 
nucleus. The mandate of the new plan could, under the right circumstances; 
foster much needed longitudinal supervision and objective scrutiny of the 
health care system. This ought to be followed by the implementation of 
significant reforms leading to better utilization of the physical plant and 
the country's valuable human resources to increase coverage and improve 
both preventive and curative care for most citizens. --mJM8IA: JEALlll SECIlR REVIEW

Water Supply and Sewerage Background :J 
1. The population of 26 million is distributed as follows: about 
65% in ,~ban areas (population centers above 2,500 inhabitants), 15% in 
rural nuclei (between 500 and 2,500 people each) and 20% in dispersed rural 
areas. 
2. In 1977 it was estimated that about three forths of the urban 
populatlon, and one fifth of the rural population (practically all in rural 
nuclei) were covered by home water delivery systems, which was equivalent 
to a 60l average for the country as a whole. 2/ Sewage was available to 
about tlo'o thirds of urban, and 7% of rural, dwellings in that year, while 
most of the balance in urban areas and rural nuclei used latrines. Since 
1969 urian water supply has barely kept pace with rapid population growth, 
while i~ rural nuclei it has improved substantially in relative terms from 
9% to 2(1% coverage. Colombia ranks ninth for water supply, and fourth for 
sewage, coverage among Latin American countries. This relatively high 
standing is due· to Government's social investment policies over the last 15 
to .20 years. 
3e Water and sewage services are handled by three separate groups of 
entities: (a) about 30 departamento and municipal public enterprises, 
which are generally responsible for the almost 50% of the people who live 
in large cities and departamento capitals; (b) the Institute for Municipal 
Development (Insfopal), an autonomous agency under the MS, which covered 
about 18% of the population living in medium and small size cities; and (c) 
the National Institute of Health (INAS), also an autonomous MS agency, res­
ponsible for the coverage of the 15% of the people who live in rural 
nuclei. INAS, however, has transferred its responsibilities to SSS in the 
departamentos of Antioquia, Valle, Cauca, Caldas, Qundio, Riseralda, and 
Tolima and its coverage has been halved as a result. It is generally felt 
that departamento and municipal enterprises provide the best water and 
sewage s~rvices, even to the extent of ranking at the top for similar 
enterprises in Latin America. Insfopal's performance is deemed very poor 
and INAS' spotty. While enterprises average number of house water connec­
tions was 360 per employee in 1978, the respective averages were from 60 to 
600 for INAS, and 180 for INSFOPAL. 
1/ 	 Much of the information in the Annex was obtained from the PAHO 
subsector report of January 1980. 
Only about 60% of 'the total number of urban centers and rural nuclei' 
received treated water, however. -108 - Annex 4

4. Overall sub-sector planning is shared by DNP and MS, the former 
through its infrastructure division's sanitary engineering unit, and the 
latter through its directorate for environmental sanitation. All tmportant 
plans and programs are presented for approval to the Technical Council for 
Economic and Social Development (CONPES) which is headed by the President 
of the Republic and the members of which are several ministers mainly 
concerned With the so called "economic" (as opposite to "social") sectors. 
The Minister of Rea1th is invited to CONPES meetings to discuss matters of 
relevance to MS. 
5. The water and sewage sub-sector depends on the MS (and specifi­
cally on the Minister himself, given the lack of institutional coordination 
between MS and the autonomous agencies) for policy and normative matters. 
Additionally, MS authorizes INSFOPAL and lNAS annual budgets and through 
this means exercises a certain degree of control over their operations. 
6. Of a total sub-sector manpower availability of about 17,400 (of 
whom 5% are professionals) distributed as follows: 7,400 among decentra­
lized public enterprises, 4,700 in Insfopal and about 3,300 in Inas. Addi­
tionally, there are about 2,000 members of administrative community coun­
cils who manage lNAS-bui1t projects but are not INAS employees, working 
instead and moreover for their respective communities. The relatively low 
share of professionals is due to their concentration among private consult­
ing firms which work for the sub-sector. There. is need, however, for cons­
tant upgrading of staff capabilities. 
7. Sub-sector financial resources have been heavily concentrated on 
the public departamento and municipal enterprises, which are mostly 
self-financed. Government budgetary allocations have been inadequate to 
cover INSFOPAL's financial needs, which resulted in increasing operating 
deficits, largely due to lack of expenditure recovery from users and to 
poor management. INAS financing is largely (88%) derived from PAN and DRI 
resources and 12% from users' contributions. Users also cover all operat­
ing costs of INAS-built facilities. In general, the degree of self-support 
is very satisfactory and among the highest in Latin America. 
8. lNAS was established in 1968 as an autonomous agency under the 
aegis of the MS and given the responsibility to develop water sup1y and 
sewage services in towns between 50 and 2,500 inhabitants. INAS is also 
responsible for the production of chemical and biological products and 
quality control of foods and beverages. lNAS also conducts applied and 
operational research for MS. 
9. INAS' overall policy planning, budgetary and operational review 
and supervision are carried out by a board the chairman of which is the 
Minister of Health, and comprising MS' directors general of environmental 
sanitation and research, and one representative each of DNP, and of 
scientific health associations. INAS director and the respective water and 
sewage, lab,oratories and research units carry out the day-to-day operati"cms -109 - Annex 4

at headquarters in Bogota. Field Qffices ,belong to th~ water and sewage, 
unit and supervise works in the lesser developed departamentos. INAS has 
established 1,740 municipal administration councils composed of community 
members to manage the system it builds. 
10. F~om the date of its establishment INAS has built about 6,000 
water supply, and 500 sewage sytems. Additionally, latrine production and 
delivery programs are carried out. These activities have benefitted 
roughly 1.7 million people (water house connections), of whom about 70% in 
rural nuclei. Sewage beneficiaries account for about a quarter of a mil­
lion people. INAS estimates that it can prepare from 200 to 250 projects a 
year if it had the necessary financing for feasibility and engineering 
studies. However, administrative and manpower constraints would have to be 
overcome also to allow this level of new works, together with the resulting 
expanded supervision and control responsibilities. 
11. INAS' 3,300 staff are distributed between headquarters (1,120) 
and field offices (2,180). Field staff visit rural nuclei and talk to com­
munity leaders about their needs. Audiovisual aids are used for the popu­
lation at large. The establishment of local councils (which include an 
INAS representative) is promoted and plans are discussed jOintly for water 
and sewage works based on a minimum 10% to 20% citizens' contribution to 
investment and full coverage of operating expenditures. The works are 
built bV INAS and technical assistance is provided for the initial period 
of operations. 
12. A preliminary review of INAS' performance indicates the need for: 
(a) centralized accounting and improved financial analysis of projects; (b) 
expansion of water treatment availability to improve impact on morbidity 
and mortality; and (c) follow up on community management of facilities for 
both improved supervision and impact measurement. Improved management 
would entitle INAS to request increases in discretionary financial alloca­
tions above the present US$10,000 limit per request, which should in turn 
improve management flexibility and performance. 
13. INAS would also benefit from improved manpower use and from addi­
tional funds to cove~ materials and equipment, since its present budget is 
almost fully used to pay staff. The most pressing investment needs are the 
re-equipment of its laboratories for research on entomology, parasitology, 
pathology, chemistry, drugs and foods; and well-drilling equipment to allow 
for,S drilling teams to drill 50 to 100 wells per departamento, which is 
considered a feasible and desirable target. 
14. In any future development plans for the subsector special atten­
tion should be paid to the strong possible role of departamento and munici­
pal enterprises, which not only have performed best in relative terms, but 
also in line with Government's decentralization plans. Any deyelopment 
effort ShbUld be closely coordinated with health care services expansion to 
obtain maximum.impact. -110 ­

Health Sector Investments 
A. The Official Sector 
Overview of the National Hospital Plan (Plan) 
1. The Plan was origfnally established by Law 12 of 1963. Law 12 
dictated that all health facility investments had to be approved by the 
Ministry of Health (MS) in line with the policy directives of the Plan as 
they would evolve through time. The Plan, to be elaborated by government, 
would include general programming, integration of public preventive, cura­
tive, teaching and research services and consideration of public and 
privati! entities. 
2. However, Law 12 was largely ineffective. The Plan was not elabo­
rated and integration and coordination of services could not even be star­
ted for lack of basic statistics, staff and central funding. Addi tiona1ly, 
the them powerful hospi tal boards (themselves heavily pol! ticized) simply 
refused to follow guidance, let alone submit to controls by MS. 
3. Decree 687 of 1967 dictated that ten percent of the ISS reserves· 
would be loaned in the form. of bonds of constant real value to a fund to be 
established, the Nat~onal Hospital Fund (FNH) for the construction and 
equipping of hospitals and other health facilities. FNH would be managed 
partly by MS and ISS and would ensure the coordination of investment pro­
grams between the two most important health-related agencies in the 
country. The ISS contributions never materialized and, lacking funds, the 
FNH languished during the next two years. 
4. In 1969 the Plan was put into effect through Law 39, which 
included 54 hospital construction and capacity expansion projects for the 
period 1970 to 1972. Central government budgeting allocations began to be 
made specifically for purposes of the Plan. This was followed in 1976 by 
Decree l21 which provided the legal framework for FNH. 
FNH Ob j.!cti ves 
5. These are essentially: (a) to elaborate the general hospital 
construction and equipment plan in line with SNS guidelines and priorities; 
(b) establish the general norms for buildings and equipment of hospitals 
and individual services; (c) provide techical assistance to all government 
levels and units; (d) finance the expansion plans through direct contribu­
tions and loans; (e) design buildings and maintenance systems to serve as 
the basis for future expansion; and (f) advise 'MS on all the above-related 
matters • Annex 10 -117 ­Page 2 
Organizational Structure 
6. Overall mangement and supervision responsibilities for FNH rest 
with the Minister of Health through MS's Directorate of Hospital Construc­
tion and Maintenance. However, its specific jurisdiction, intra-Ministry 
and interagency relations have never been defined. 
7. FNH's organization structure consists of the director general, a 
deputy director and five line divisions: technical studies (which analyzes 
plans and specifications and equipment lists of proposed project, as well 
as establishes general construction and equipment norms); project implemen­
tation, maintenance, financial and administrative. Two committees advise 
Management, one for technical matters and another for equipment purchases. 
Staffing

58 professionals, 41 technicians and 108 administrative staff for a total

9. FNH has no well-defined policies or programs. It simply reacts

a national health care plan with well-defined and coordinated goals.
